<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/23  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 390, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[752, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 361, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 73, 124, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 625, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 101, 613, 120]]<|/det|>
\[c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 168, 88]]<|/det|>
## Formulae

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 106, 561, 144]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 527, 180]]<|/det|>
\[W = \rho \Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 195, 537, 223]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 235, 527, 252]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 263, 561, 295]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V}\langle c^2\rangle\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 305, 537, 321]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 339, 613, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_{0}\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_{0}^{2} - \chi^{2})}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 380, 537, 415]]<|/det|>
\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}V}{\nu\pm\nu_{s}}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 425, 537, 460]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 467, 628, 486]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_{1} + 1 / C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 500, 598, 519]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_{1} + C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 529, 527, 556]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 570, 531, 588]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 603, 598, 622]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 637, 628, 655]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 668, 517, 702]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 715, 558, 733]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 747, 581, 766]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 777, 536, 812]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[295, 71, 700, 89]]<|/det|>
Answer **all** the questions in the spaces provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 102, 96, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 146, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 102, 594, 121]]<|/det|>
An electromagnetic wave has a wavelength of \(85 \mu \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 181, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 133, 526, 152]]<|/det|>
State the wavelength, in m, of the wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 178, 920, 197]]<|/det|>
<form>wavelength = .................................................... m [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 209, 181, 228]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 209, 564, 228]]<|/det|>
Calculate the frequency, in THz, of the wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 317, 920, 337]]<|/det|>
<form>frequency = ................................................. THz [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 349, 181, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 349, 900, 368]]<|/det|>
State the name of the region of the electromagnetic spectrum that contains this wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 380, 920, 398]]<|/det|>
<form>............................................................................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 411, 146, 429]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 411, 920, 445]]<|/det|>
The current \(I\) in a coil of wire produces a magnetic field. The energy \(E\) stored in the magnetic field is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 454, 534, 484]]<|/det|>
\[E = \frac{I^2L}{2}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 492, 339, 510]]<|/det|>
where \(L\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 523, 920, 558]]<|/det|>
The manufacturer of the coil states that the value of \(L\), in SI base units, is \(7.5 \times 10^{-6} \pm 5\%\). The current \(I\) in the coil is measured as \((0.50 \pm 0.02) \text{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 570, 534, 588]]<|/det|>
The values of \(L\) and \(I\) are used to calculate \(E\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 600, 611, 619]]<|/det|>
Determine the percentage uncertainty in the value of \(E\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[374, 802, 920, 821]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = ................................................. % [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 833, 920, 852]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 601, 89]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by the centre of gravity of a body.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 101, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 144, 920, 163]]<|/det|>
<form>........................................................................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 164, 920, 182]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 194, 146, 212]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 194, 920, 228]]<|/det|>
A uniform wooden post AB of weight \(45\mathrm{N}\) stands in equilibrium on hard ground, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[277, 234, 715, 380]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 395, 591, 414]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 426, 920, 490]]<|/det|>
End A of the vertical post is supported by the ground. A horizontal wire with tension \(T\) is attached to end B of the post. Another wire, attached to the post at point C, is at an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) to the horizontal and has tension \(38 \text{N}\). The distances along the post of points A, B and C are shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 183, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 504, 920, 537]]<|/det|>
Calculate the horizontal component of the force exerted on the post by the wire connected to point C.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[319, 580, 920, 599]]<|/det|>
<form>horizontal component of force = .................................................... N [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 612, 181, 630]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 612, 715, 630]]<|/det|>
By considering moments about end A, determine the tension \(T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 765, 920, 784]]<|/det|>
<form>T = .................................................... N [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 797, 180, 816]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 797, 808, 816]]<|/det|>
Calculate the vertical component of the force exerted on the post at end A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 890, 920, 908]]<|/det|>
<form>force = .................................................... N [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 921, 920, 938]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
A ball is fired horizontally with a speed of \(41.0 \text{m s}^{-1}\) from a stationary cannon at the top of a hill. The ball lands on horizontal ground that is a vertical distance of \(57 \text{m}\) below the cannon, as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 128, 845, 320]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 349, 591, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 380, 410, 399]]<|/det|>
Assume air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 411, 146, 429]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 411, 831, 429]]<|/det|>
Show that the time taken for the ball to reach the ground, after being fired, is 3.4 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 551, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 583, 146, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 583, 920, 616]]<|/det|>
Calculate the horizontal distance of the ball from the cannon at the point where the ball lands on the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 675, 920, 694]]<|/det|>
<form>horizontal distance = ............................................... m [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 706, 144, 725]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 706, 920, 739]]<|/det|>
Determine the magnitude of the displacement of the ball from the cannon at the point where the ball lands on the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 860, 920, 878]]<|/det|>
<form>displacement = .................................................... m [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 489, 89]]<|/det|>
The ball leaves the cannon at time \(t = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 3.2, sketch a graph to show the variation of the magnitude \(\nu\) of the vertical component of the velocity of the ball with time \(t\) from \(t = 0\) to \(t = 3.4 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 448, 151]]<|/det|>
Numerical values are not required.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 158, 631, 316]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 335, 532, 352]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 350, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 380, 144, 399]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 380, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
The cannon recoils horizontally with a speed of \(0.340 \text{m s}^{-1}\) when it fires the ball. The total mass of the ball and the cannon is \(1480 \text{kg}\). Assume that no external horizontal forces act on the ball-cannon system.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 443, 641, 460]]<|/det|>
Determine, to three significant figures, the mass of the ball.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[519, 628, 920, 645]]<|/det|>
<form>mass = .................................................... $kg$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[910, 628, 920, 645]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 660, 144, 678]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 660, 888, 678]]<|/det|>
The cannon now fires a ball of smaller mass. Assume that air resistance is still negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 691, 920, 724]]<|/det|>
State and explain the change, if any, to the graph in Fig. 3.2 due to the decreased mass of the ball.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 817, 920, 835]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 831, 920, 850]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 311, 89]]<|/det|>
State Hooke's law.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[88, 165, 123, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 165, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
A spring is fixed at one end. A compressive force \(F\) is applied to the other end. The variation of the force \(F\) with the compression \(x\) of the spring is shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[262, 207, 730, 381]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 399, 532, 418]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 432, 920, 450]]<|/det|>
Show that the elastic potential energy of the spring is \(0.64 \text{J}\) when its compression is \(16.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 571, 920, 590]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 602, 144, 620]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 602, 920, 635]]<|/det|>
The spring in **(b)** is used to project a toy car along a track from point X to point Y, as illustrated in Fig. 4.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 642, 823, 812]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 828, 591, 847]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.2 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 860, 920, 925]]<|/det|>
The spring is initially given a compression of \(16.0 \text{cm}\). The car of mass \(0.076 \text{kg}\) is held against one end of the compressed spring. When the spring is released it projects the car forward. The car leaves the spring at point X with kinetic energy that is equal to the initial elastic potential energy of the compressed spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 920, 103]]<|/det|>
The car follows the track around a vertical loop of radius \(0.12 \text{m}\) and then passes point Y. Assume that friction and air resistance are negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 243, 134]]<|/det|>
Calculate:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 181, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 149, 400, 166]]<|/det|>
the speed of the car at X

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 255, 920, 274]]<|/det|>
<form>speed = .................................................... $\text{ms}^{-1}$ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 288, 181, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 288, 683, 306]]<|/det|>
the kinetic energy of the car when it is at the top of the loop

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 490, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
<form>kinetic energy = .................................................... J [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 523, 180, 541]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 523, 403, 541]]<|/det|>
the speed of the car at Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 584, 920, 603]]<|/det|>
<form>speed = .................................................... $\text{ms}^{-1}$ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 616, 148, 635]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 616, 920, 648]]<|/det|>
In practice, a resistive force due to friction and air resistance acts on the car so that its kinetic energy at Y is 0.23 J less than its kinetic energy at X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 661, 853, 680]]<|/det|>
Determine the average resistive force acting on the car for its movement from X to Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 836, 920, 853]]<|/det|>
<form>average resistive force = .................................................... N [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 866, 920, 885]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 12]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
A sound wave is detected by a microphone that is connected to a cathode-ray oscilloscope (CRO). The trace on the screen of the CRO is shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 112, 769, 355]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 370, 532, 388]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 401, 603, 420]]<|/det|>
The time-base setting of the CRO is \(2.0 \times 10^{- 5} \text{s} \text{cm}^{- 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 433, 181, 452]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 432, 561, 452]]<|/det|>
Determine the frequency of the sound wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[482, 555, 920, 574]]<|/det|>
<form>frequency = .................................................... Hz

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 588, 180, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 586, 920, 621]]<|/det|>
The intensity of the sound wave is now doubled. The frequency is unchanged. Assume that the amplitude of the trace is proportional to the amplitude of the sound wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 634, 650, 652]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 5.1, sketch the new trace shown on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 634, 920, 653]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 664, 180, 683]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 664, 482, 683]]<|/det|>
The time-base is now switched off.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 695, 517, 714]]<|/det|>
Describe the trace seen on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 756, 920, 775]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
A beam of light of a single wavelength is incident normally on a diffraction grating, as illustrated in Fig. 5.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[270, 112, 725, 263]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 281, 591, 300]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.2 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 312, 920, 361]]<|/det|>
Fig. 5.2 does not show all of the emerging beams from the grating. The angle between the second-order emerging beam and the central zero-order beam is \(16^{\circ}\). The grating has a line spacing of \(3.4 \times 10^{-6} \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 375, 181, 393]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 375, 500, 393]]<|/det|>
Calculate the wavelength of the light.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 497, 920, 515]]<|/det|>
<form>wavelength = .................................................... m [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 529, 181, 548]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 529, 722, 548]]<|/det|>
Determine the highest order of emerging beam from the grating.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 668, 920, 686]]<|/det|>
<form>highest order = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 699, 920, 717]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 494, 90]]<|/det|>
Define electric potential difference \((p.d.)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 163, 146, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 920, 197]]<|/det|>
A wire of cross-sectional area \(A\) is made from metal of resistivity \(\rho\). The wire is extended. Assume that the volume \(V\) of the wire remains constant as it extends.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 210, 808, 228]]<|/det|>
Show that the resistance \(R\) of the extending wire is inversely proportional to \(A^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 365, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 396, 144, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 396, 920, 429]]<|/det|>
A battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(E\) and internal resistance \(r\) is connected to a variable resistor of resistance \(R\), as shown in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[329, 435, 662, 586]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 604, 532, 622]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 635, 395, 653]]<|/det|>
The current in the circuit is \(I\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 666, 490, 684]]<|/det|>
Use Kirchhoff's second law to show that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 692, 551, 720]]<|/det|>
\[R = \left(\frac{E}{I}\right) - r.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 823, 920, 841]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 918, 109]]<|/det|>
An ammeter is used in the circuit in **(c)** to measure the current \(I\) as resistance \(R\) is varied. Fig. 6.2 is a graph of \(R\) against \(\frac{1}{I}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[207, 116, 784, 408]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 426, 534, 444]]<|/det|>
<mark>[b]> 6.2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 457, 181, 475]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 456, 920, 490]]<|/det|>
Use Fig. 6.2 to determine the power dissipated in the variable resistor when there is a current of 2.0A in the circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 611, 920, 630]]<|/det|>
<form>power = .................................................... $W$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 642, 180, 660]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 641, 514, 660]]<|/det|>
Use Fig. 6.2 and the equation in **(c)** to:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 673, 223, 691]]<|/det|>
<label>1.</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[233, 673, 589, 691]]<|/det|>
state the internal resistance \(r\) of the battery

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[561, 718, 920, 737]]<|/det|>
<form>r = .................................................... $\Omega$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 751, 220, 769]]<|/det|>
<label>2.</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 751, 537, 769]]<|/det|>
determine the e.m.f. \(E\) of the battery.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 873, 920, 892]]<|/det|>
<form>E = ............................................................ V

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 890, 920, 908]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 921, 920, 938]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[824, 945, 920, 962]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Turn over

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 860, 92]]<|/det|>
Two vertical metal plates are separated by a distance \(d\) in a vacuum, as shown in Fig. 7.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[299, 98, 695, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 272, 591, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 7.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 303, 920, 354]]<|/det|>
The potential difference (p.d.) between the plates is \(V.\) A nucleus with charge \(+q\) is initially at rest on plate X. The nucleus is accelerated by the uniform electric field from plate X along a horizontal path to plate Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 364, 146, 383]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 364, 648, 383]]<|/det|>
State expressions, in terms of some or all of \(d\), \(q\) and \(V,\) for:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 396, 181, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 395, 544, 414]]<|/det|>
the magnitude of the electric field strength

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[393, 457, 920, 476]]<|/det|>
<form>electric field strength = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 488, 181, 507]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 488, 658, 507]]<|/det|>
the magnitude of the electric force acting on the nucleus

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 565, 920, 584]]<|/det|>
<form>force = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 597, 180, 616]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 597, 665, 615]]<|/det|>
the kinetic energy of the nucleus when it reaches plate Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 674, 920, 693]]<|/det|>
<form>kinetic energy = ........................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 705, 148, 724]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 705, 920, 739]]<|/det|>
State the change, if any, in the kinetic energy of the nucleus on reaching plate Y when the following separate changes are made.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 752, 181, 770]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 752, 675, 770]]<|/det|>
The distance \(d\) is halved, but the p.d. \(V\) remains the same.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 782, 920, 801]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 814, 181, 833]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 814, 920, 848]]<|/det|>
The nucleus is replaced by a different nucleus that is an isotope of the original nucleus with fewer neutrons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 860, 920, 878]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
The nucleus is carbon-14 ( \(^{14}_{6}\mathrm {C}\) ). This nucleus decays to form a new nucleus by releasing a \(\beta ^{- }\) particle and only one other particle of negligible mass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 181, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 119, 803, 138]]<|/det|>
Calculate the nucleon number and the proton number of the new nucleus.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 197, 917, 214]]<|/det|>
<form>nucleon number = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 228, 920, 246]]<|/det|>
<form>proton number = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 244, 920, 262]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 274, 180, 293]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 274, 598, 293]]<|/det|>
State the name of the particle of negligible mass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 306, 920, 325]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]
